title: Agent: Discarding new files should also remove empty folders
body:
1. Implement a new feature with Agent mode, creating lots of new pages, components and utils in new folders
2. Decide that this wasn't the right approach
3. Discard and start anew
4. 🐛 Any newly created folders pile up in the workspace
5. 🐛 Agent mode keeps getting confused by empty folders, browsing their content

cc @lszomoru maybe discard in SCM can handle that as well

body:

3. 🐛 Discarding changes in SCM causes the working set to keep/apply outdated changes; creating discarded files.

Expected: When I stage, commit or discard files in SCM, Agent should reflect that as kept/discarded in the working set.

title: Enhance Todo list widget with comprehensive keyboard navigation and accessibility features
body:
This PR addresses the accessibility limitations of the Todo list widget by implementing comprehensive keyboard navigation and ARIA support, making it fully accessible for keyboard-only users and screen reader users.

## Problem

The current Todo list widget had significant accessibility barriers:
- No keyboard navigation between todo items
- Missing ARIA labels and roles for screen readers
- No keyboard shortcuts for common actions (mark complete, edit, etc.)
- Limited focus management when expanding/collapsing
- Poor experience for users relying on assistive technologies

## Solution

### Keyboard Navigation
- **Arrow keys (↑↓)**: Navigate between todo items with wrapping at boundaries
- **Enter/Space**: Toggle todo status through the cycle: not-started → in-progress → completed → not-started
- **Tab**: Proper focus order between expand button and todo list
- **Escape**: Collapse expanded list and return focus to expand button
- **Ctrl/Cmd + Enter**: Quick mark as completed
- **Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + Enter**: Quick mark as in-progress

### ARIA Accessibility (WCAG 2.1 AA Compliant)
- Added `role="listbox"` to todo container with descriptive `aria-label`
- Todo items use `role="option"` with unique IDs and comprehensive `aria-label` including title, status, and description
- Implemented `aria-selected` and `aria-activedescendant` for proper focus tracking
- Added screen reader announcements for status changes using `aria.alert()`
- Maintained existing `aria-expanded` state management

### Focus Management
- Clear visual focus indicators using VS Code's standard focus styling
- Focus preservation during status changes and list updates
- Proper focus restoration when expanding/collapsing
- Safe navigation boundaries with comprehensive edge case handling

### Implementation Details
```typescript
// Example of ARIA label generation
const ariaLabel = todo.description 
    ? localize('chat.todoList.itemWithDescription', '{0}, {1}. {2}', todo.title, statusText, todo.description)
    : localize('chat.todoList.item', '{0}, {1}', todo.title, statusText);

// Status change announcement
const message = localize('chat.todoList.statusChanged', '{0} is now {1}', todo.title, statusText);
aria.alert(message);
```

## Testing

- Created comprehensive unit tests for keyboard navigation logic
- Validated ARIA label generation and status cycling behavior
- Tested edge cases: empty lists, single items, focus restoration
- Manual testing guide included for QA verification
- Screen reader compatibility verified for Narrator, VoiceOver, and NVDA

## Files Changed

- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatContentParts/chatTodoListWidget.ts` - Main implementation
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/media/chat.css` - Focus styling and visual indicators
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/test/browser/chatTodoListWidget.test.ts` - Unit tests

The implementation follows VS Code's accessibility patterns and coding standards while maintaining backward compatibility. All functionality remains available via mouse interaction, with keyboard navigation as an additional enhancement.

Fixes accessibility barriers and improves the experience for all users, especially those using keyboard-only navigation or assistive technologies.

title: Add left and right padding to notebook cell editors for suggestion widget spacing
body:
This fixes an issue where suggestion widgets in notebook cells were overlapping with cell borders, causing poor visual spacing and readability issues.

## Problem

As shown in the issue, suggestion widgets (like autocomplete dropdowns) in notebook cells were appearing too close to or overlapping with the cell border outline. The suggestion widget would touch the left edge of the cell, creating a cramped appearance without proper visual separation.

## Root Cause

Notebook cell editors only had top and bottom padding configured (`top: 12, bottom: 12`), but no left or right padding. Since notebook cells use a 1px outline with `-1px` offset for focus indicators, suggestion widgets could overlap with this visual border element.

## Solution

Added minimal left and right padding (`left: 1, right: 1`) to the editor configuration in `cellEditorOptions.ts`. This ensures suggestion widgets maintain proper spacing from the cell border while preserving all existing functionality.

The fix is surgical - only two properties added to the existing padding object:

```typescript
// Before
...{ padding: { top: 12, bottom: 12 } },

// After  
...{ padding: { top: 12, bottom: 12, left: 1, right: 1 } },
```

## Impact

- Suggestion widgets now have proper 1px spacing from notebook cell borders
- Improved visual clarity and readability in notebook cells
- No impact on other UI elements or functionality
- Minimal performance impact

Fixes #261526.

title: Feature Request: Configurable Reasoning Settings and API Connection Test for GPT-5
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, the VS Code does not provide full configuration support for reasoning models (e.g., GPT-5 and other Azure reasoning-enabled models). While basic integration is possible, several important customization options are missing.

I’d like to request the following features:

1. Reasoning Control

- Ability to set reasoning levels: Low, Medium, High
- Option to adjust reasoning verbosity (concise vs. detailed explanations)

2. Multiple Deployment Profiles

- Ability to configure and save multiple model deployments with different settings (e.g., Low reasoning vs. High reasoning)
- Quick switching between profiles for different workflows

3. Token Configuration

- Option to define input and output token limits per deployment
- Useful for balancing cost, performance, and response length

4. Reasoning Trace Visibility

- Option to view reasoning traces (where supported by Azure)
- Improves debugging, evaluation, and prompt optimization

5. Request Caching for Custom API Keys

- Ability to cache API requests by default when using custom Azure API keys
- Reduces latency, improves performance, and avoids redundant calls for repeated queries

6. Connection & API Testing

- When adding a reasoning model like GPT-5, provide an option to test the connection by sending a sample request and verifying the response
- Ensures configuration is valid before use in development workflows

At present, the VS Code does not expose these options, even though they are supported in Azure AI Foundry. Enabling them would unlock the full potential of GPT-5 and other reasoning models directly within the IDE.

title: Remember Activity Bar view container between restarts

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: **Desired situation** Please let VS Code remember which Activity Bar view container (Explorer, Search, Source Control, Extensions, or an extension-contributed view) was last active and reopen that same one when you restart VS Code. If it's implemented as a preference and not as a default behaviour, please change the default behaviour to always open the first view container in the activity bar instead of the Explorer view container. **Current situation** The default behaviour does not restore the last selected view container in the Activity Bar. On restart, it always defaults back to Explorer (the file tree). There is currently no setting in settings.json to change this behavior. No preference "window.restoreActivityBarView": "true" exists. Reordering the desfired view container to be first in the activity bar also doesn't work.

title: Don't make the up arrow wrap when terminal suggest widget is not focused

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body: Something that bugs me slightly with terminal suggest is that I often write a command prefix in zsh and then use the up arrow to cycle through my history (e.g. `gc -m "some message"` that fails precommit hooks, I fix it and then gc+up arrow to try again). However this gets captured by terminal suggest. I think this is actually case where there is _no_ utility in using the up arrow, because that immediately wraps to the end of the suggested command list -- which is something I can't see and is the least-relevant suggestion. Can we make it so that the up arrow doesn't trigger focus to move into terminal suggest?

title: Fix task process command absolute path handling
body:
When configuring tasks with `"type": "process"` and absolute paths in the command field, VS Code was incorrectly prepending the workspace directory in certain scenarios, leading to invalid paths like `/workspace/C:\Python\python.exe` or `/workspace/usr/bin/python`.

## Problem
The issue occurred in the `_resolveAndFindExecutable` method in `terminalTaskSystem.ts`. The original logic would:

1. Call `findExecutable` to locate the command
2. If found, use that result (which could be incorrect for absolute paths)  
3. Only check if the command was absolute as a fallback when `findExecutable` failed

This meant that when `findExecutable` returned unexpected results for absolute paths, the user's explicit absolute path specification was ignored.

## Example Issue
```json
{
  "version": "2.0.0",
  "tasks": [
    {
      "label": "Run Python",
      "type": "process",
      "command": "C:\\Python\\python.exe",
      "args": ["--version"],
      "options": {
        "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

With the original logic, this could result in an incorrect path like `C:\workspace\python.exe` instead of the intended `C:\Python\python.exe`.

## Solution
Moved the absolute path check to occur **before** the `findExecutable` call:

```typescript
// Check for absolute path first
if (path.isAbsolute(command)) {
    return command;
}

// Only use findExecutable for relative paths
const foundExecutable = await systemInfo?.findExecutable(command, cwd, paths);
if (foundExecutable) {
    return foundExecutable;
}
return path.join(cwd ?? '', command);
```

This ensures that when users specify absolute paths, they are respected exactly as written, while maintaining all existing functionality for relative paths.

## Testing
The fix has been thoroughly tested across multiple scenarios:
- ✅ Absolute paths on Windows (drive letters and UNC paths)
- ✅ Absolute paths on Unix-like systems
- ✅ Relative paths continue to work unchanged
- ✅ Variable resolution (e.g., `${workspaceFolder}/python.exe`) works correctly
- ✅ All `findExecutable` behaviors for relative paths preserved

This is a minimal, surgical fix that resolves the core issue while maintaining full backward compatibility.

Fixes #262544.

body:

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: Arch Linux up to date and Debian 12. Both using XFCE.

## Issues

There are multiple things that need to be configurated to be able to see the issues. It is for this reason that I created a repository with everything ready: https://github.com/AndresMunozDeveloper/vscode-tree-view-api-issues

There are 4 issues.

### Cannot select multiple nodes

With the configuration in the repository, I cannot select multiple nodes, the selection behaves strangely.

Compare what's visibly selected to what show the logs: https://github.com/AndresMunozDeveloper/vscode-tree-view-api-issues/blob/main/src/extension.ts#L48

### Clearing the selection by pressing Esc leaves a focused node

I was expecting that when I press the Esc key and I call a command, the focused node would be undefined but instead it is the last focused node.

Select a node, then press Esc to deselect, then call a command, and check what the logs show: https://github.com/AndresMunozDeveloper/vscode-tree-view-api-issues/blob/main/src/extension.ts#L55

### Keybindings do not pass the focused node to the commands

When I see a focused node, I'm expecting to receive that node as a parameter even when using keybindings.

Focus a node and call a command using a keybinding and then check the logs: https://github.com/AndresMunozDeveloper/vscode-tree-view-api-issues/blob/main/src/extension.ts#L55

### Cannot programatically collapse or expand the nodes

I like to save the state of the tree of nodes including their collapsed state, but this is not possible with the current behavior, it just ignores the state I'm trying to set.

I cannot make the Collapsed All Nodes and Expand All Nodes work by setting the TreeItem collapsibleState property: https://github.com/AndresMunozDeveloper/vscode-tree-view-api-issues/blob/main/src/extension.ts#L108

body:

<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:  (fill your version here, e.g. 1.94.2)
- OS Version:  (fill your OS here, e.g. Windows 11 / Ubuntu 22.04)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the **Live Server** extension in VS Code.
2. Open an `index.html` file.
3. Right-click → **Open with Live Server**.
4. When it opens in VS Code’s **Simple Browser (embedded preview)** → the screen is completely **black**.
5. If I instead open the same page in an **external browser** (Chrome/Edge/Firefox), the page loads correctly and is visible.

Expected behavior:  
- Live Server preview should render the page normally in VS Code’s Simple Browser.  

Actual behavior:  
- The Simple Browser shows only a **black screen**, while external browsers display the content correctly.  

Additional Notes:  
- I tested disabling extensions; this only occurs when using the built-in Simple Browser.  
- Live Server itself is serving correctly because the page works fine in external browsers.  
- Issue seems related to VS Code’s Simple Browser rendering, not Live Server itself.

title: clean up: change static method into service
Allow modals in automation
body:
This allows for the opt-in behavior of allowing dialogs while using automation. I went with opt-in to reduce the blast radius (our smoke tests assume dialogs don't show).

When opted in, we also switch over to using custom dialogs & the simple file picker so that the automation can control it.

This was added so that we can do auth flows, which uses dialogs. Now we will be able to complete an auth flow (with the help of the user in the browser) and automate interacting with chat via the development MCP server.

title: two monaco-editors in different theme
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Suppose two monaco-editors are rendered simultaneously on a page
- one is the main editor and the other is a small editor in the lower right corner. 
- The main editor requires a global theme style, while the small editor requires a local theme.
**How can this be achieved?**


### Here is my demo。I Love VSCode
**standaloneThemeService**
```diff --git a/node_modules/monaco-editor/esm/vs/editor/standalone/browser/standaloneThemeService.js b/node_modules/monaco-editor/esm/vs/editor/standalone/browser/standaloneThemeService.js
index 045ad4c..d206b86 100644
--- a/node_modules/monaco-editor/esm/vs/editor/standalone/browser/standaloneThemeService.js
+++ b/node_modules/monaco-editor/esm/vs/editor/standalone/browser/standaloneThemeService.js
@@ -328,6 +328,42 @@ export class StandaloneThemeService extends Disposable {
         TokenizationRegistry.setColorMap(colorMap);
         this._onColorThemeChange.fire(this._theme);
     }
+    // Force fetching the theme styles for local mounting to override global styles.
+    _updateThemeOrColorMapStandalone(desiredThemeName, domNode, cssscope) {
+        const standaloneclassName = 'standalone-theme'
+        domNode.classList.add(standaloneclassName);
+        const desiredTheme = this._knownThemes.get(desiredThemeName) || this._knownThemes.get(VS_LIGHT_THEME_NAME);
+        const cssRules = [];
+        const hasRule = {};
+        const ruleCollector = {
+            addRule: (rule) => {
+                if (!hasRule[rule]) {
+                    cssRules.push(rule);
+                    hasRule[rule] = true;
+                }
+            }
+        };
+        themingRegistry.getThemingParticipants().forEach(p => p(desiredTheme, ruleCollector, Object.create(null)));
+        const colorVariables = [];
+        for (const item of colorRegistry.getColors()) {
+            const color = desiredTheme.getColor(item.id, true);
+            if (color) {
+                colorVariables.push(`${asCssVariableName(item.id)}: ${color.toString()};`);
+            }
+        }
+        ruleCollector.addRule(`.${standaloneclassName} .monaco-editor, .${standaloneclassName} .monaco-diff-editor, .${standaloneclassName} .monaco-component { ${colorVariables.join('\n')} }`);
+        const colorMap = /* this._colorMapOverride ||  */desiredTheme.tokenTheme.getColorMap();
+        ruleCollector.addRule(generateTokensCSSForColorMap(colorMap, standaloneclassName));
+        const themeCSS = cssRules.join('\n');
+        const codiconCSS = this._codiconCSS;
+        const allCSS = `${codiconCSS}\n${themeCSS}`;
+        
+        const styleElement = dom.createStyleSheet(domNode, style => {
+			style.className = 'monaco-colors';
+			style.textContent = `@scope (${cssscope}) {${themeCSS}}`;
+		});
+        return styleElement;//  !!!mount this to the container node of the editor.!!!
+    }

title: VSCode gets stuck in re-selecting the same cell in Jupyter Notebook (ExtHostNotebook#$acceptEditorPropertiesChanged)

labels.name: freeze-slow-crash-leak
labels.description: VS Code crashing, performance, freeze and memory leak issues

body:
Type: Bug Hi there, Lately, I've been encountering an issue where VSCode becomes partially unresponsive while working with .ipynb files. After extended sessions of editing a notebook file, incl. kernel restarts, output clearing, and cell execution, the interface starts misbehaving; most notably, the menus become unusable. When I try to open any menu, it briefly flashes and then immediately closes. Looking into the "Extension Host" traces, I noticed a flood of `ExtHostNotebook#$acceptEditorPropertiesChanged` entries appearing every few milliseconds. It appears as if VSCode continuously re-selects the most recently used cell or repeatedly detects its selection. This behavior persists even when another file is opened in the editor. However, the messages stop and VSCode's UI becomes responsive again once the notebook file is closed. I compared notebook usage under typical conditions, and confirmed that those events are logged only when a new cell is selected. The excessive logging appears only when VSCode enters this problematic state. It’s a strange issue, but I hope this description helps clarify what’s happening. VS Code version: Code 1.103.1 (360a4e4fd251bfce169a4ddf857c7d25d1ad40da, 2025-08-12T16:25:40.542Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes: Remote OS version: Linux x64 6.6.87.2-microsoft-standard-WSL2
